text: Using this form to think aloud. I just came across a really old note about IUPAC naming in chemistry. Maybe particularly in organic chemistry. I wondered if there is a similar naming standard in the world of software. If so can someone point out to me?

elements.text: Using this form to think aloud. I just came across a really old note about IUPAC naming in chemistry. Maybe particularly in organic chemistry. I wondered if there is a similar naming standard in the world of software. If so can someone point out to me?

text: It does not have to be successful or adopted. I’m just looking for some effort that might have gone into this direction.

elements.text: It does not have to be successful or adopted. I’m just looking for some effort that might have gone into this direction.

text: Do you have a good link where those unfamiliar with IUPAC naming can learn what it is?

elements.text: Do you have a good link where those unfamiliar with IUPAC naming can learn what it is?

text:
I don't think it is possible. In chemistry, you know what your elements are. In coding, you don't, there could be many different ones. You could just name all your functions based on a lambda calculus like SKI and then name them according to their implementation, but almost every function of interest can be implemented in multiple ways. And there is no (general) way to figure out if two implementations are equivalent.

Put differently: maybe it is possible, but if it is, we haven't figured out the foundational science needed to do something like IUPAC.

What one could do is to have names that are not meaningful and build a catalog of IDs to functions, but that's very different from IUPAC.

text:
I think it would be an interesting exercise <@UEUTBH4V7>! You should go for it. I can't think of any off the top of my head. If there is one, I bet Mathematica would have incorporated it.

Looks like IUPAC was formed in 1919. If you were doing something similar today, you could do it on Git, and make your standards in a computational language.

Off the top of my head some of the meta categories would be:

`*NumeralMap
*BooleanOp
*Machine
*Lang
*Function
*CharacterMap
*Pattern`
